Sem N., 39, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She supports her family by selling vegetables in the market and is able to earn US$6 of profit every day. Her husband is a construction foreman and makes US$10 per day. This couple has one little child.

Mrs. Sem N. would like to take out a loan to purchase construction materials for her husband.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Rin C., 37 years old, resides in Kampong Cham Province where she works in a grocery store, making approximately $1.50 of profit every day, while her husband earns $3 per day selling recycling items. This couple has three children, one who is a student and two who are employed. Mrs. Rin C. is asking for a loan to expand her grocery’s inventory.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for the store.

loans.name: Son

texts.en: Mr. Son S., 37, owns a brick-oven with which he makes charcoal to sell from his home. His wife, Chrep, 34, raises pigs for sale. They have one young child, not yet enrolled in school. Because the family's house is too old and small for them, Mr. S. would like a loan to add to his personal saving to build a new one. The loan will help the family attain a comfortable living. The picture shows Mr. S.'s wife because he was not available.

loans.use: To build a new house.

loans.name: Fahriddin

texts.ru:
Фахриддин Точибоев  мужчина 34 года, женат на Саодат Обиловой, имеет 1 ребёнка. Супруги проживают в Шахристанском районе и занимаются животноводством и переработкой молока. 
 Фахриддин обратился в "Микроинвест" для того,  чтобы получить займ в размере 1600 сомони, сроком на 6 месяцев.
 После получения займа планирует потратить его на закуп корма для скота и переработки молока.
texts.en:
Fahriddin T. is a 34-year-old man, who is married to Saodat Obilova and has one child. The couple lives in the Shahristan region and raises livestock and sells dairy products. Fahriddin turned to MicroInvest for a six-month loan in the amount of 1600 somoni. Once he has received the loan, Fahriddin plans to spend it on the purchase of cattle feed and milk production.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising cattle and selling dairy products

loans.name: Song

texts.en: Song S. T., 42, is married and resides in Kampong Cham Province where she works in a grocery store and earns about $7 per day, while her husband, a motor-taxi driver, has an income of about $5 per day. This couple has three school-aged children. Song S. T. would like to take out a loan to increase her stock of grocery items.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for the store.

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun N. Y., 40, lives with her husband and three of their children in Kampong Cham Province, where she sells vegetables and grocery items, on average earning $10 in revenue per day. Her husband is a taxi-driver who also makes $10 per day. Two of her children have a business cleaning motorbikes. Soun N. Y. is asking for a loan to increase her grocery inventory.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her business.

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
Penh M., 35, is a modest women who lives in Kompong Tom Province in Cambodia. Here she earns a living breeding many pigs in her own stall behind her house. She sells all her pigs to the slaughterer when they are mature. She is married with two children; both of them are minor and under her care.

To help provide the family's meals, her husband sells firewood and charcoal in the family home. To make transportation easier in that business, Penh M. is looking for a loan to buy buffalo that she can connect to her existing trailer-cart so she can use it to transport firewood and charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To buy buffalo to pull her cart

loans.name: Mrs. Vanna Phat Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Village Bank, which consists of thirteen members, is located in Trapeang Trayueng village in Takeo province. The members plan to use the loan they obtain for different purposes. Mrs. Vanna P. is the Village Bank president, and was selected by the members. She is a weaver. Since her work is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more weaving supplies. Her husband, Mr. Meas Hoeun, is a security guard. Mrs. Vanna P. is a 27-year-old mother of a child who is too young to work or stuD.. Mrs. Diyana P. does not come to take a loan but her husband does, so he is presented in the picture instead.

One member in this group has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Purchasing more weaving supplies.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov P. lives in Sophy village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Additionally, she is a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing five more piglets and pig food; she would use the rest of money to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

Mrs. Pov P. is a 47-year-old widow with four children, three of whom are machine repairers, while the other is attending the local school. She is presented with her child in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase five more piglets, pig food, and a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Om

texts.en: Mrs. Om G. is a 57-year-old widowed mother of five children - two of whom are married and live separately, whilst the other three are single. Two of G.'s single children are employed - one daughter works as a garment worker in Phnom Penh City, and one son is a firewood seller. Presently, G. sells carving wood that she and her son carved from the forest, and is earning around $6 per day to manage the family's daily expenses. The family intend to build a house but their personal savings are still not enough to pay for it. Therefore, G. has decided to seek a loan to put with her savings to begin building a house.

loans.use: To build a house

loans.name: Zhkera Group

texts.en: Zhkera is the group leader of Zhkera group. There are three members in this group. They want to expand their businesses and make them larger. Zhkera wants to take out a loan for her tailoring business. Sheullah wants to take out a loan for her quilt making business. Moaui wants to take out a loan for her father who makes cauldrons. They are requesting a group of loan 42000 Afghani for the term of 10 months. They are happy about this process of loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: to expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Kamal

texts.en:
Kamal A. J. is 28-years-old, married, and has five children. He lives in Nablus city, Palestine. For a living, Kamal sells coffee and tea in a kiosk, which he owns. With this activity he helps support his children and cover the family needs. 
Kamal is requesting a loan for US $1000 to expand his business by increasing his working capital. He and his family are very grateful for the support that you give to allow them to continue their business and improve their quality of life.

loans.use: to expand his business, increasing his working capital

loans.name: Tin

texts.en: Mr. Tin K. lives in Moeun Tom Rang village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Ream Mom, owns a poultry business. Since her ducks are growing bigger and bigger, she can not support them. Thus, Mr. Tin K. decided to request a loan to buy duck food for his wife’s poultry business. He is 43 years old and the father of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is enrolled in the local school. His wife is shown with him in the picture.

loans.use: to buy duck food for his wife’s poultry business.

loans.name: Mwfa’

texts.en:
Mr. Mwfa’ T. is a very hardworking man who sells a variety of goods in his mini grocery store. Mwfa’ wants to improve his living standard, which is the reason why he is spending most of his time in managing his business.

Mwfa’ needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of his goods. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting a loan of 3000USD. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of his goods

loans.name: Karema Group

texts.en: Karema is the group leader of Karema group. There are three members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan for the success of her business. Karema wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. Bebe Zenat wants to take a loan for her son who has a mobile-selling business. Bebe Saieda wants to take a loan for her bakery business. They are all very happy for this opportunity of a loan.

loans.use: for business progress.

loans.name: Ehgamnazar

texts.ru:
Животноводство для Эгамназара Точибоева является основным источником доходов в его семье.        Животноводством Эгамназар занимается с 20 лет, покупает домашний скот, откармливает его и перепродает на рынке Истаравшана.
  На полученный доход от животноводства содержит свою семью. Родился Эгамназар в 1973 году, получил среднее образование. Женился на Гулчехре Таджибаевой, имеет 4 детей.
  Эгамназар запрашивает сумму 1600 сомони,для того чтобы увеличить количество своего домашнего скота. Дополнительный семейный доход получает от выращивания сельхозкультур.
texts.en:
Raising livestock is Ehgamnazar T.'s main source of family income. He has been in the business of purchasing domesticated cattle and fattening them for resale at the Istaravshan market since he was 20 years old. With the income he receives from the livestock, he supports his family. Ehgamnazar was born in 1973, and completed his secondary school education. He is married to Gulchehra Tajibaeva, and has four children. Ehgamnazar is requesting 1600 somoni to increase the size of his herd. He earns additional family income growing crops.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising cattle and increasing herd size

loans.name: Ahmad Zuvdiun

texts.en:
Ahmad Zuvdiun is the son of M.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married, has two children and he needs a small loan for his business. He wants to expand the shop where he sells clothes. 

He is requesting an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani ($1025 US) for the term of 12 months. He wants to expand and increase his business and to complete the necessary materials for his shop. 

He is very happy with this small loan effort in Afghanistan that helps poor people. He thanks all lenders of AFS and Kiva.

loans.use: For business expansion and progress: clothes shop.

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.ru:
Нуриддин Шамсиев мужчина 36 лет, холост, проживает в Шахристанском районе. Животноводством он занимается 4 года, ткармливает домашний скот у себя дома. Дополнительный доход Нуриддин имеет от выращивания сельхозкультур. Займ хочет получить для откорма домашнего скота.
 Запрашиваемая сумма 1600 сомони сроком на 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Nuriddin S. is a 36-year-old man, and a bachelor who lives in Shahristan region. He has raised livestock for four years, fattening domesticated cattle at his home. Nuriddin earns additional income raising crops. He wants the loan to fatten his cattle, and has requested a six-month loan in the amount of 1600 somoni.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising cattle

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 44 years old and mother to 2 children. Esther makes photocopies, computer designs and she also has a computer school in Lagos state, Nigeria. Esther is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN120, 000 ($825 US) to purchase a computer and a photocopier. This, she says, will enable her to satisfy the growing demands of her numerous customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase a computer and a photocopier for her business.

loans.name: Muhammad Asaf

texts.en: Muhammad Asaf is the son of H.. He lives in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has four children. He is a tailor and he works hard to earn money for his family’s requirements. He needs to buy a new sewing machine for his shop because he has had a lot of problems, during sewing, with the old sewing machine. In addition, he wants to expand his business and to hire a student to help him. He wants to take an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani ($1025 US) for the term of 12 months and he is very glad that he has the chance to progress.

loans.use: To buy and new sewing machine for tailoring business.

loans.name: Inobat

texts.ru:
Инобат  Нарзуллоевой 62 года, проживает в городе Истаравшане. Инобат вдова, у нее 5 детей.Около 6 лет Инобат торгует на вещевом рынке, продает национальные головные уборы - тюбетейки.
  Планирует разнообразить ассортимент своего товара, с этой целью обратилась к нам. Запрашиваемая  сумма займа 2500 сомони на 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Inobat N. is 62 years old and lives in the city of Istaravshan. Inobat is a widow with five children. For six years, Inobat has worked at the clothing market, where she sells traditional caps, the tubeteika (skullcaps; see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tubeteika). She is planning to diversify her selection of goods and with this goal in mind came to MicroInvest, requesting a six-month loan in the amount of 2500 somoni.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of traditional caps

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen sells wholesale oranges to her customers. She travels to Edo state to purchase her oranges and sells them in Lagos state. Queen is 44 years old, married, and has 5 children. Queen is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN120,000 ($825 US) to purchase more oranges to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more oranges to sell.

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en: Abiola sells onions. She has 2 grinding machines that she uses to grind pepper, tomatoes and beans in her shop. Abiola is 46 years old, married, and has 5 children. Abiola is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN 70,000 ($475 US) to purchase more onions to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more onions to sell.

loans.name: Mariétou

texts.fr:
Madame Mariétou  T.est âgée  de 48 ans, mariée et mère de 7  enfants, elle vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, ses  deux coépouses et leurs enfants dans le quartier Hamdallaye   de la préfecture  de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, elle s’est très vite initiée aux activités génératrices de revenus, auprès de sa maman. Après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle décida finalement de faire l’achat et la vente des habillements notamment la vente des layettes  il y a de cela 15 ans. Cette activité est rentable et lui procure assez de  revenus. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire et satisfaire sa clientèle, Madame Mariétou n’a pas pris du temps pour rejoindre l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso. En six ans de relation avec l’institution, elle a correctement remboursé ses  4 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe) et ses 3 prêts individuels.
Elle est à son quatrième prêt  individuel  qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une importante quantité de layettes (de qualités et de couleurs différentes)  à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Elle effectue sa vente  dans le grand marché de Koutiala  à une clientèle composée de femmes et hommes à crédit ou au comptant.  
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70.000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt,  participer aux  dépenses quotidiennes  de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariétou Tounkara, age 48, is married and the mother of seven. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her two co-wives, and their children in the Hamdallaye district, in Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to go to school, she very soon got introduced by her mother to earning revenues. After having worked at several kinds of businesses unsuccessfully, she finally decided fifteen years ago to buy and sell clothing, particularly baby wear. This is a profitable business, which brings in a fair income for her.

Concerned about increasing her turnover and satisfying her customers, Ms. Mariétou wasted no time in joining the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. During her six years associated with the institution, she has correctly repaid her four solidarity loans (group loans) and her three individual loans. She is now on her fourth individual loan, which will be used to buy a sizable quantity of baby wear (of good quality and of different colors) in Bamako (capital of Mali). She makes her sales at the grand marketplace of Koutiala to customers composed of women and men, cash or credit accepted.

She plans to realize a monthly profit of 70,000 francs CFA she envisions using to make loan interest payments, to help cover day-to-day family expenses, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing for babies

loans.name: Haitham

texts.en:
A married father of one, Mr. Haitham H. is 39 years old. The college cafeteria has become an important source of income for Haitham’s family. This is where he operates now. Haitham’s friendly manner has made the cafeteria into a place that is very popular with the college students. 

Due to the requests he receives daily from his regular customers, he wants to increase his stock of products. In order to do this, Haitham is requesting a loan of $3000. He hopes you will be able to help him.

loans.use: To increase his inventory in the cafeteria.

loans.name: Kotognontala (Let's Speak The Same Language) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognontala est un regroupement de femmes du quartier de Hamdallaye Koutiala (région de Sikasso) qui se connaissent bien. Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris et  leurs enfants. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, sont mariées et sont  mères d’au moins 4 enfants. 
Elles mènent  une seule activité à savoir la teinture et vente d’habillements.
Pour augmenter la taille de leur activité, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 75.000 FCFA pour le troisième prêt. Tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, des bazins, de la   teinture, de la soude caustique et d’autres ingrédients.
Elles se procurent  de leurs marchandises à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Elles vendent les bazins, tissus et pagnes finis (c’est-à-dire teints de colories et de motifs différents)  au grand marché Koutiala et dans les marchés environnants.
Les membres du groupe Kotognontala comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 90 000 FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle. En plus du remboursement des intérêts du prêt, elles utiliseront une partie du revenu pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Kotognontala is a group of women of the Hamdallaye Koutiala district (region of Sikasso) who know one another well. They live in large traditional families with their husbands and children. They average 30 years of age, are married, and are mothers with at least four children.

The group members have a sole business, namely dyeing cloth and selling clothing. To expand their business, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. The loan amounts have gone from 50,000 francs CFA for the first loan up to 75,000 francs for the third loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The current loan will be used to buy damask fabrics, dyes, caustic soda, and other ingredients. Supplies are gotten in Bamako (capital of Mali). The damask, cloth, and finished pagnes (that is, dyed lengths of cloth of different colors and motifs) are sold at the grand market of Koutiala and in surrounding marketplaces.

The group members plan on realizing a profit of 90,000 francs CFA each in the course of this cycle. In addition to making loan interest payments, they will use a portion of the revenues to address common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy damask fabrics and ingredients for dyeing cloth

loans.name: Amudat

texts.en: Amudat sells clothes and sachet water in her shop. Amudat is 45 years old, married, and has 2 children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN100, 000 ($700 US). This loan will help her to purchase more clothes and sachet water to sell. She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and sachet water for her shop.

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke sells clothes and baby items (baby cream, soap, shoes, etc.). She is 33 years old, married, and has 4 children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 70,000 ($475 US) to purchase more clothes and baby items to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and baby items to sell.

loans.name: Chioma

texts.en: Chioma is 43 years old, married, and has 6 children. She sells kerosene, both wholesale and retail, to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 140,000 ($950 US) to purchase more kerosene to sell. She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
Since she was a small girl, Saodat has been entirely dedicated to her work. She buys and sells cattle. Until now this has been the most important source of income for her. Her work consists of raising beef cattle and, after fattening them, she sells at the best price and makes a profit. In the future, she wants to start another business. In the meantime she will continue dedicating herself to cattle-raising.

Right now she wishes to expand her business and purchase more cattle. This is the reason that Saodat has asked for a loan of $600.

By helping in this loan, you could become an important part in Saodat's family's life: she deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the site of the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle.

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en:
Titilayo sells grocery provisions in retail to her customers. She hopes to obtain a loan amount of N50,000 to allow her to purchase more provisions to sell. She is 35 years old and married with six children.

Titilayo sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Simiatu

texts.en:
Simiatu is 43 years old and married with seven children.She runs a restaurant business, where she sells cooked foods, local gin, and other drinks. She hopes to obtain a loan amount of N50,000 in order to purchase more local gin and drinks to sell in her restaurant.

Simiatu sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin and other drinks to sell in her restaurant.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin is 35 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She is a tailor and also sells tailoring materials such as zippers, thread, etc. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 ($350 US) so that she can purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

loans.name: Akmaljon

texts.en:
A. Akmaljon is 27 years old. He is married and has no children yet. His mother and father live with him and he is responsible for their living expenses too. He has a butcher shop and has been running the meat selling business for 3 years. He provides meat for the markets and his family with necessary food. Now, Akmaljon is requesting a loan of $ 600 USD and plans to pay it off within 12 months. Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro entrepreneur and his experience in the business, this customer is qualified to receive this loan. Akmaljon is counting on your help. Your support will really help him.

loans.use: To purchase meat to expand his butcher's shop business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 39 years old. She is married and has 2 children. Esther is a tailor and she also sells tailoring materials. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 ($350 US) to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

loans.name: Umeda

texts.en:
M. Umeda is 22 years old. She is not married and lives with her parents. For more than 2 years, Umeda has been running her own business. Umeda has a small salon where she sells and rents out Traditional and the National-style wedding dresses. Traditionally, families in Tajikistan are large. Consequently there are lots of marriages and Umeda has a lot of clients. The stability of her business allows her to make a considerable contribution to her family’s income. Umeda requests $600 US, with which she is going to purchase one new wedding dress. Umeda would like to assure to all lenders who decide to support her that she will pay off the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase of new wedding dress for rental business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing the range of vegetables in his produce shop.

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en:
Bosede is 60 years old. She is a widow with eight children. She sells foodstuffs and provisions.

She is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 so that she can purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchsae more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Abdujabbor

texts.en:
N. Abdujabbor, 34, is married with three children. Abdujabbor runs his own café, where he cooks and serves shish kebab. His café is located close to his house. He has been in this business for three years. Abdujabbor tries to use only the best ingredients in his café, and he believes it is for this reason that the business is stable and brings considerable income for the family.

Abdujabbor is planning to expand his business so that he may earn more money. With this purpose in mind, Abdujabbor is requesting a loan of $700 for the term of 12 months. He is planning to purchase the meat and coal that he needs for preparing shish kebab in his café.

Abdujabbor wants to thank everyone who is supporting him.

loans.use: To purchase the meat and coal that he needs for preparing shish kebab in his café.

loans.name: Zarif

texts.en:
Y. Zarif is 27 years old. He and his wife are raising three children. Zarif is an experienced bread baker and has been engaged in this business for more than eight years. He bakes the national bread, “lepeshka,” at home, with the help of his wife. Zarif sells the majority of his product from his home, where he has many customers, but he also runs a trading place in the local marketplace, where he sells his ”lepeshka” at market.

Zarif is requesting $600 for the term of 12 months. He is planning to purchase flour wholesale.

Zarif is grateful to all who choose to support him, and he promises to manage the loan with accuracy and timeliness.

loans.use: Purchasing flour wholesale in order to bake lepeshka for sale.

loans.name: Kudirat

texts.en: Kudirat, 35 years old and married with four children, is a tailor who makes lovely designs for her customers.  She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sew more clothes for her customers. Kudirat thanks Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials.

loans.name: Linette

texts.en:
Linette A. O. is a 30-year-old mother of two children ages 9 and 7. She is married to a “casual-worker," which, in the U.S., is similar to a day laborer. She lives in Nyamasaria slum where she sells beans, rice, dengu, and green grubs. She uses the profits to help her children go to school and plans on sending them to college through university. She says she sees the value in education. Linette says that her husband does not work very hard, a common theme amongst borrowers here in Kisumu, and she enjoys running her own business because it gives her the opportunity to raise her children on her own. She is asking for 10,000 KSH (or about $150 US) to increase the amount of goods in her kiosk.

Linette recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: School fees; food goods for her kiosk

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo produces and sells cellophane bags to her customers. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira (or about $350) to purchase more materials to make more cellophane bags. Taiwo is 47 years old and is a widow with 3 children. She thanks all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make more cellophane bags

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 40 years old and married with 7 children. She sells dried fish and other foodstuffs. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira (or about $700 US) to purchase more foodstuffs and dried fish to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela is 46 years old and is married with 8 children. She sells bed sheets, shirts, and curtains to her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira (or about $700 US) to purchase more bed sheets and curtains to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bed sheets and curtains to sell

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo is a tailor who also sells tailoring materials. Sheis requesting a loan of 60,000 Nigerian naira (or about $425 US) to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. Titilayo is 39 years old and married with 5 children. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Vitali

texts.en: Vitalie works together with his wife and they own a store of different products like: washing powder, cosmetics and hair accessories. Vitalie works with the delivery of cargo from wholesale bases to their store. He deals with the marketing of various products in a shop in the Criuleni town. He rented the store 3 years ago, now Vitalie and Maria are satisfied in their business. Both have reached a conclusion that they need to increase the stock of goods and therefore have borrowed a sum of 25,000 Moldovan Leu from Microinvest to develop business.

loans.use: Increase store inventory

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
Comité Renacer, asi de denomina el comité conformado en fecha 17 de diciembre de 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General, la Sra.Laura R. contactó con la asesora para informarse de como funciona el Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de Fundacion Paraguaya.  Una vez enterada logró conformar un comité con 19 mujeres, quienes se encuentran trabajando en el 2º ciclo del programa.

El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de 500.000 Gs., lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de mercerías, venta de mercaderias para la despenza (arroz, azúcar, fideos, lacteos, panificados, yerba, etc), venta de ropas, venta de cosméticos y perfumes, venta de carnes, venta de remedios refrescantes, ect.

Todas ellas estan trabajando en forma conjunta y solidaria, ayudandose mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.

Laura R. - 	Despensa - 
Lorenza Cáceres  - 	Despenza - 
Raquel A. - 	Venta de carne - 
Marcelina C.  - 	Venta de ropas - 
Ambrosia M. - 	Venta de carne - 
Juliana S.	- Venta de lencerias - 
Mirtha Benítez - 	Venta de frutas - 
Benita S. -  	Venta de ropas - 
María Quiroga - 	Copetín - 
María A. - 	Venta de ropas - 
Abelina V.	 - Venta de frutas - 
Josefina V.	- Venta de frutas - 
María M. - 	Venta de ropas - 
María Fernández	 - Despensa - 
Delcy P.	 - Venta de ropas - 
Mariacita González	- Venta de carnes - 
Elsa R.	- Venta de mercerias - 
Rosa S.	- Venta de remedios refrescantes - 
Lorenza Martínez	- Venta de cosméticos -
texts.en:
Comité Renacer is the name of the committee constituted on December 17, 2008, thanks to when the current Director General, Mrs. Laura R., contacted the advisor to find out how the Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de Fundación Paraguaya (Program for Women Entrepreneurial Committees Paraguayan Foundation) worked. Once she was well-informed, she managed to constitute a committee of 19 women who are now working in the second cycle of the program. The average loan withdrawn for each member is for 500,000 Gs, which will be intended for different activities such as hardware sales, sales of foodstuffs (rice, sugar, pasta, dairy products, baked goods, yerba tea, etc.), clothing sales, cosmetics and perfume sales, meat sales, traditional medicine sales, etc. All of the women are working in a united and jointly-shared way, mutually helping themselves to arrive at their common objectives, which they all have within the group and with the Fundación Paraguaya. Laura R. - food store Lorenza Cáceres - food store Raquel A. - meat shop Marcelina C. - clothing shop Ambrosia M. - meat shop Juliana S. - linen shop Mirtha Benítez - fruit shop Benita S. - clothing shop María Quiroga - liqueurs/spirits María A. - clothing shop Abelina V. - fruit shop Josefina V. - fruit shop María M. - clothing shop María Fernández - food store Delcy P. - clothing shop Mariacita González - meat shop Elsa R. - hardware shop Rosa S. - traditional medicine shop Lorenza Martínez - cosmetics shop

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs (rice, sugar, yerba tea, dairy products, baked goods, carbonated beverages, etc.), purchase of clothing, purchase of hardware, purchase of cosmetics and perfumes, purchase of fruit, purchase of traditional medicines, purchase of linens, etc.

loans.name: Teodor

texts.en: B. Teodor is a truck driver. He transports in his truck furniture from Romania. He has 3 children, two daughters and one boy who is the youngest. Teodor has only this job that he loves and with which he supports his family. He wants to change the truck's tires because they are pretty old and at the same time to fix some defects in the motor because he did not restore the engine a very long time ago. Teodor borrowed a loan from Microinvest of 30,000 Moldovan Leu to purchase new tires.

loans.use: New tires and engine maintenance

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She sells foodstuffs and she has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama K. is thirty-five years old. She is divorced and has given birth to two children, a son and a daughter. Both of her children are in the primary school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. As a single parent, she works very hard to be able to provide for the family.

Mariama is a food vendor. She prepares and sells porridge in the mornings. She prepares the porridge from ingredients such as millet, maize, beans, etc. She sells on the street.

Mariama has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business. She is hopeful to give her children the best of education.

loans.use: To buy maize, millet, etc. to prepared cooked food for sale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel A. is a twenty-six-year-old unmarried man but the father of a three-year-old son who is currently in primary school. Emmanuel lives alone in a rented apartment in a town called Takorase. Takorase is farming and a commercial community in the Eastern Region of Ghana. He says his son lives with his mother. However, Emmanuel provides for all his needs.

Emmanuel sells DVDs, tape cassettes, and other items. He sells the items in a shop in the local lorry station. He buys his products from wholesale dealers in the nearby bigger towns. Emmanuel has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure more DVDs and cassettes in bulk. He is hopeful to give his child the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To procure cassettes and DVDs for re-sale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa B. is forty-one years old. She is married and has given birth to one child, a daughter. She says her daughter who is a hairdresser is currently married and lives with her husband.

Yaa lives with her husband and two other dependents in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She is a businesswoman. She sells second-hand textiles – clothes for both sexes and also bedsheets.

Yaa procures bales of textiles from Accra and sells in her community by hawking. She says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for five years and desires to expand her business. Yaa is hopeful to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To procure second-hand textiles for re-sale

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Jiguiya est  constitué de quatre femmes  mariées dont deux polygames et deux monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et  3 enfants. Elles habitent à Sanoubougou I  un des  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur  cinquième   collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin de leurs  clientèles et augmenter leur profit. Tous les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de pagnes, de condiments alimentaires,  de savons et la teinture. 
Elles comptent acheter  20 pièces de pagnes wax, 20 pièces de bazin pour la teinture, 30 paniers de condiments, 20 cartons de savons  et des ingrédients pour la teinture. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, de Bamako (la capitale du Mali) et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville,  à domicile et  de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider les maris et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Jiguiya  ambitionnent de devenir des  grossistes.
texts.en:
The group Jiguiya is composed of four women, two polygamous and two monogamous. They average 37 years of age and three children each and live in Sanoubougou I, a district in Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group members are on their fifth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers and to increase their profit. All the preceding loans have been repaid.

The group members do a diversity of work, including selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth), condiments, soap, and dyed cloth. They intend to buy 20 bolts of Wax pagnes, 20 bolts of damask fabrics for dyeing, 30 baskets of condiments, 20 boxes of soap, and some ingredients for dyeing cloth. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City, in Bamako (capital of Mali), and in surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold retail to customers composed of women and men, cash or credit accepted, at the grand market of Sikasso City, at home, and door-to-door.

They each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 19,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used to help their husbands, and the other portion will be invested in business and used to repay the loan. Their ambition is to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome O. is thirty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, two sons and a daughter. She says all of her children are currently in primary school. She lives with her husband and the children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Salome is a businesswoman. She sells second-hand textiles – clothes for both sexes and also bedsheets. She procures bales of textiles from Accra and sells in her community by hawking. She says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days as well. Salome says she has been in business for five years and desires to expand her business. She is hopeful to expand her business and be able to send her children to the higher levels of academia.

loans.use: To procure second-hand textiles for re-sale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa O. is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, one son and two daughters. She says all of her children are out of school and working. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. Her husband is a cocoa farmer.

Yaa is a businesswoman. She runs a provisions store on one of the principal streets in her community. She also sells vegetables and other food items on a small table top in front of her store. She procures her goods from wholesalers in Oda and other nearby towns. Yaa has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business. She is hopeful to expand her business.

loans.use: To procure provisions for re-sale

loans.name: Keleya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe  Keleya  sont toutes mariées dans des familles  monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et  3 enfants. Elles habitent à Sanoubougou I un des  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  3ème région administrative de la république du Mali.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de pagnes, de produits de beauté et de  savons. 
Elles sont à leur  cinquième   collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but  de  satisfaire le besoin de leur  clientèle et augmenter leur profit. Tous les prêts précédents se sont   bien dénoués. 
Elles comptent acheter , 50 pièces de pagnes, 30 cartons de produits de beauté et 30 cartons de savons.  Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, Bamako et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place et  de façon ambulante au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider les maris et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Keleya  ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Keleya are all married in monogamous families and average 39 years of age and 3 children each. They live in Sanoubougou I, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and do a diversity of work, including selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth), beauty products, and soaps. They are on their fifth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of satisfying the needs of their customers and to increase their profit. All the preceding loans have been settled.

The group members intend to buy 50 bolts of pagnes, 30 boxes of beauty products, and 30 boxes of soap. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City, in Bamako, and in surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold on credit at the retail level to customers composed generally of women at the grand market of Sikasso City, locally, and door-to-door.

The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used to help their husbands, and the other portion will be invested in business and used to repay the loan. Their ambition is to become wholesale merchants.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. is forty-one years old. She is married and has given birth to six children: two daughters and four sons. All of her children are in junior high or primary school. Janet lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a farming and commercial town called Takorase, which is near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Janet works to support her husband financially in providing for the family, especially the children’s education. Her husband is a farmer who cultivates food crops. Janet trades in fried fish. She procures fresh fish in cartons from nearby cold store operators and fries them herself. She distributes to food vendors and sells some herself by hawking. Janet has been in business for three years. She wants a loan to procure fish in bulk to expand her business. She is hopeful that she will be expand her business and give her children the best education.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish in bulk.

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Soutoura est  constitué de sept femmes  mariées dont trois polygames et quatre monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent à Sanoubougou I  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur  cinquième   collaboration avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de  satisfaire le besoin de la  clientèle et augmenter leur profit. Tous les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés.
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente  de pagnes,  de condiments alimentaires,  des fruits et  des céréales.
Elles comptent acheter,  30 pièces de pagnes, 20 paniers de condiments, 30 colis de fruits et 20 sacs de100 kg de céréales. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant et en détail.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider les maris et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Soutoura ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The Soutoura group is composed of seven married women (three polygamous and four monogamous), who average 38 years of age and 4 children. They live in Sanoubougou I, one of the neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. They are seeking their fifth loan from Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, in order to better meet customer demand and increase their profits. All previous loans were repaid without problems.

They run various businesses, among others : selling pagnes (colorful African cloth), food condiments, fruits, and cereals. They intend to buy 30 pieces of pagnes, 20 baskets of condiments, 30 boxes of fruits, and 20 100-kg sacks of cereals. They get their supplies at the grand market in Sikasso and in the surrounding villages. They retail their goods for cash at the grand market in Sikasso, at home, and as traveling saleswomen, to a clientele comprising both women and men.

They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 19'000 (ca US$ 40) each, to be used in part to help their husbands. The remainder will be used to repay the loan and to invest into their businesses. The women of the Soutoura group ambition to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items, such as pagnes (colorful African cloth), condiments, fruits, and cereals

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty K. is thirty one years old. She is married and has given birth to four children: two daughters and two sons. All of her children are in junior high or primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a farming and commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works to support her husband financially to provide for the family, especially the children’s education. Her husband is a cocoa and palm nut farmer.

Gifty trades in corn dough. She procures bags of maize from farmers in the nearby communities and converts it to dough. She distributes the corn dough to food vendors and sells the rest by hawking. Gifty has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk to expand her business. She hopes to give her children the best education.

loans.use: To bags of maize in bulk.

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Jiguisseme est  constitué de cinq femmes  mariées dont deux vivent dans des familles polygames et les trois autres, monogames. Elles ont en  moyenne  38 ans et  4 enfants. Elles habitent à Kaboila, une des  communes rurales  de la préfecture  de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur  dix-neuvième   collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de pouvoir davantage satisfaire le besoin de la  clientèle et augmenter leur chiffre d’affaire. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans problème. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de pagnes,  de noix de néré, du charbon de bois et du sounbala (ingrédient pour la sauce). Avec ce nouveau  prêt, elles comptent acheter  30 sacs de 100 kg de noix de néré pour préparé le sounbala,  20 sac de 100 kg de néré pour les revendre, 50 sacs de charbon de bois et  35 pagnes wax. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso sur place et souvent de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée majoritairement  de femmes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille (tel la santé  des enfants)  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Jiguisseme ambitionnent d’agrandir leurs activités.
texts.en:
The group Jiguisseme is composed of five married women, two of whom live in polygamous families, and the other three, monogamous. The women average 38 years of age and four children each. They live in Kaboila, a rural town of Sikasso prefecture (third administrative region of Mali).

They are on their 19th collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to do more in satisfying customers and to increase their sales figures. All the preceding loans have been repaid without a problem.

The group members do a diversity of work, including selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth), néré nuts, charcoal, and sounbala (an ingredient in making sauces).

With this new loan, they intend to buy thirty 100-kg sacks of néré nuts for making sounbala, twenty 100-kg sacks of néré for reselling, fifty sacks of charcoal, and 35 Wax pagnes. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City and in surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold retail, cash or credit accepted, at the grand market of Sikasso City, locally, and door-to-door to customers composed mostly of women

The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 23,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used for family needs (such as the children's health), and the other portion will be invested in business and used to repay the loan. Their ambition is to expand their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is 48 years old and married with five children. She sells sarongs by hawking them within her community in Lagos State, Nigeria.

Comfort is hoping for a loan in the amount of N80,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet O. is forty two years old. She is married and has given birth to four children: one son and three daughters. One child is currently learning a trade while the rest are in junior high or primary schools. Janet lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a farming and commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works to support her husband financially to provide for the family. Her husband is a cocoa farmer.

Janet is a food vendor. She cooks and sells banku, which is cooked corn dough served hot either with soup or pepper. She prepares and sells the food in the local government school compound. Janet procures bags of maize and other ingredients from nearby markets. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk. Janet is hoping to give her children the best education.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize in bulk.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca M. is a 28 year old mother of three children, ages 11, 8, and 6. All of her children are in school. She is originally from Kissi in Kenya, but married a man from Kisumu. Rebecca says she likes it here, but misses the cooler climate of Kissi. She runs a small kiosk in the Nyamasaria slum where she sells cereals like beans and rice. She uses the income to pay her children's school fees. This is her first loan and she is asking for 10,000 KSH.

Rebecca recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW, she will be trained by K-MET and begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutri Flour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: To expand her business selling cereals.

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Kotognogontala est  constitué de cinq femmes  mariées  vivant dans des familles polygames  avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et  5 enfants. Elles habitent à Kaboila une des  communes rurales  de la préfecture de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Afin de  satisfaire le besoin de leurs  clientèles et augmenter  davantage leurs bénéfices, les femmes du groupe  sont à leur  dix-neuvième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés.
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente des matières en plastique, du charbon de bois et du sounbala (ingrédient pour la sauce). 
Elles comptent acheter,  60 sacs de 100 kg de noix de néré pour préparer le sounbala , 70 sacs de charbon de bois et  50 colis de matières en plastique. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place et souvent de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour la scolarité  et la santé  des enfants  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
texts.en:
The Kotognogontala group consists of five married women living in polygamous families, with an average age of 40 and an average of five children. They live in rural communities in the Sikasso prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of Mali.

To satisfy the needs of their clients and increase their profits, the women of the group are on their nineteenth collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. The preceding loans were reimbursed well. They manage various activities: selling plastic materials, coal from wood, and sounbala (an ingredient for sauce).

They count on buying sixty 100 kg sacs of néré nuts to prepare the sounbala, seventy sacs of coal, and fifty packages of plastic materials. They sell their goods at the large market (the Grand Marché) in the city of Sikasso and in the surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold at the Sikasso Grand Marché on the spot to a clientele composed of men and women, either in cash or with credit. They hope to come to a point when each can earn an average monthly profit of 20 000FCFA, of which a part will be used for the education and health of their children and the other part to be invested in their activities and the reimbursement of the loan.

Translated from French by Laura Buhler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various supplies.

loans.name: Gerardo Porfirio

texts.es: El señor Gerardo Porfirio C. , tiene la edad de 47 años , habita en el barrio el raizon , carretera hacia Masaya , junto a su esposa , la cual es ama de casa y comerciante , para apoyarlo con los gastos del hogar , ya que ellos tiene a su cargo dos hijos los cuales le apoyan con los trabajos agrícolas , los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida y darle un mejor bienestar , don Gerardo desde hace 35 años , se dedica a la agricultura , el inicio la actividad agrícola con el apoyo de sus padres . Los planes hacia un futuro para su cultivo es poder mejorarlo. El financiamiento lo quiere para la compra de insumos y fertilizantes, para obtener una buena cosecha y vender a buen precio en el mercado.
texts.en:
Mr. Gerardo Porfirio C. is 47 years old and lives in the Raizon neighbourhood, on the highway to Masaya, with his wife. She is a housewife and works as a merchant in order to help him with household expenses. They also have in their charge their two sons, who help with the work on the farm. His plans for his family are to improve their quality of life and their well-being. Gerardo has been a farmer for 35 years. He began his agricultural activities with the support of his parents. His plan for the future of his crops is to be able to improve them. He wants the loan for the purchase of supplies and fertilizers in order to get a good harvest and to sell it for a good price at the market.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies and fertilizers in order to improve crops.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa B. is 40 years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, four sons and two daughters. Some are out of school and currently learning trades. Others are still in the senior high and the junior high schools. Her husband is a cocoa farmer. Yaa lives with her husband and their children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. 
Yaa is a trader. She trades in smoked fish. She procures the goods from nearby towns and sells on a table top in the market square. Yaa has been in business for three years and wants to expand her business. She is hopeful to improve her standard of living and give her children the best education.

loans.use: To procure smoked fish in bulk

loans.name: Agnetter Akumu

texts.en:
Agnetter Akumu O. is the 48-year old mother of six children, ages 26-15. Her first child has already finished college and her second is currently attending college. All the others are in secondary school. She is married to a farmer and keeps a small plot of land in the Siaya district, just outside Kisumu. She says because her husband is not really around and doesn't help with the children, she sells maize and vegetables here in Kisumu at local markets to pay school fees. She is asking for 10,000 KSH to purchase chicks so she can keep chickens and sell eggs. In addition she will be purchasing more seeds for her farm. 

Agnetter recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and seeds

loans.name: Jesus Demarche Group

texts.en:
The “Jesus Demarche” or “Jesus is working” Group is made up of fifteen male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their 1st and 2nd loans, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their 3rd loan. Their businesses range from charcoal sales to cleaning materials for the home.  Ylda M. is one of three representatives of the group. 
Ylda sells a variety of items ranging from sugar to cleaning powders to cold drinks and candies. She is thankful for her loans because she was able to purchase several animals and further furnish her home with the increased profits from her business.  Ylda contributes the increased number of children attending school to the loans and the growth of businesses in the area. Ylda dreams of expanding her business and continually moving forward. On behalf of Ylda, Jesus Demarche, and Esperanza, we thank you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, cleaning powders, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is 36 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters. Some of her children are in the junior high school and others are in the primary school. Her husband is a cocoa farmer. Ama lives with her husband and the children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Ama is a trader. She trades in smoked fish. She procures the goods from nearby towns and sells on a tabletop in the market square. Ama has been in this business for more than 15 years and desires to expand her business. Ama is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To procure smoked fish in bulk

loans.name: Maryline

texts.en:
Maryline A. O. is a 28-year-old mother of five children, ages 9, 7, 4, 2 and a half, and 6 months. She sells second-hand clothes that she purchases from wholesalers in the Kiubye market, Kisumu’s largest open air market. On average, Maryline says she makes 4,000 KSH a week and sometimes more on Sunday, market day. She is married to a businessman but they want to set up another account dedicated to her business. She is asking for 10,000 KSH to buy more stock. If she makes enough profit, she would like to start selling shoes, purchased from Dubai. She hopes to send her children through university because, “that is the good life."

Maryline recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Clothing Stocks, Shoes

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua A. is forty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters. She says all of her children are in junior high and primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. Her husband is a cocoa farmer.

Akosua is a businesswoman. She runs a provisions store on one of the principal streets in her community. She procures her goods from wholesalers in Oda and other nearby towns. Akosua has been in business for over eight years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business. She is hopeful to expand her business.

loans.use: To procure provisions for re-sale

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles O. is a 26-year-old father of one child, age 4. He sells new clothes and particularly enjoys selling suits in the Nyamasaria slum. He is always looking for business, including from this interviewer. He wants to buy more clothes because he believes with more options, more customers will come to his shop. He is asking for 10,000 KSH to build out his stall to accommodate more stock.

Charles recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW he will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of his community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. His work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: buying more new clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama M. is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to five children, two sons and three daughters. Some are in senior high and others in junior high schools. Her husband is a cocoa farmer. She lives with her husband and the children in a family house in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Ama is a businesswoman. She sells both washing and toilet soap in the local market. Ama says she also hawks in her community and treks to other markets to sell her products. Ama procures the soap from wholesalers in the nearby communities at reasonable prices. She has been in business for eight years and desires to expand her business. She wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best of education.

loans.use: To procure cartons of soap

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa S. is forty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters. She says one of her children is in the university. The others are in senior high and junior high schools. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works to assist her husband financially to provide for the family. Her husband is a cocoa farmer.

Theresa is a businesswoman. She runs a provisions store on one of the principal streets in her community. She procures her goods from wholesalers in Oda and other nearby towns. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business. She is hopeful to expand her business and give her children a sound education.

loans.use: To procure provisions for re-sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice G. is a 49-year-old married mother of six children. She sells charcoal, vegetables and fruits. She is asking for 10 000 KES to purchase more charcoal (in bulk) and vegetables. As making charcoal is now illegal in most parts of Kenya, Eunice buys her charcoal at Dunga Beach on Lake Victoria, where boats come in from Uganda. Eunice says her two biggest challenges are lack of money, and inability to transport the charcoal from the lake to Nyamasaria slum, where she lives and sells the charcoal. In addition, because she sells vegetables and fruits in Kibuye market, she spends lots of money transporting herself and her goods between the three areas.

Eunice recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal, vegetables, fruit, and transport

loans.name: Pedro Pablo

texts.es: El señor Pedro Pablo O. , tiene la edad de 40 años , habita en el bario san Francisco de lomas el Gavilán , junto a su esposa la cual se desempeña como docente , para apoyar con los gastos familiares , ellos tiene a su cargo dos hijos , un varón de 11 años , estudiante de sexto grado de primaria y una niña de seis , estudiante de tercer grado de primaria , los planes hacia su familia es poder apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios y se realicen como unos grandes profesionales ; don Pedro desde hace 20 años se dedica a la actividad agrícola , el mayor problema que se le ha presentado es la falta de financiamiento , el quiere diversificar sus cultivos para obtener mejor ingresos . El financiamiento lo quiere para  comprar insumos agrícolas y poder mejorar el cultivo para tener una buena producción. Da las gracias Afodenic por el apoyo para sobresalir con sus siembras, lo cual beneficia a las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Pedro Pablo O. is 40 years old and lives in the San Francisco de Lomas el Gavilán district with his wife, who works as a teacher to help with household expenses. They have two children, a boy 11 years old, studying in sixth grade, and a six-year old girl in third grade at primary school. The plans for his family are to be able to help their children in their studies and to help them become great professionals. Don Pedro has been farming for 20 years. The biggest problem that he faces is a lack of financing. He wants to diversify his crops to get a better income. He would like financing to buy farming materials and to be able to improve cultivation to obtain a good yield. He gives thanks to Afodenic for the help to excel with his sowing, which benefits the needs of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase materials and fertilizers to improve cultivation

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 49-year-old married mother of eight children. Her husband does not work so to help keep her children in school Joyce sells cereals such as maize, rice and beans. She purchases them in Busia, Kenya, on the Ugandan border. She is asking for 10 000 KES to increase her food stock so she can sell more. Her main challenges are inadequate capital, a high inflation rate, transport, and feeding her children.

Joyce recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: To increase her stock of cereals

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris Y. is a 45-year-old married mother of three children. Her son and two daughters are still in school – one in senior high, one in junior high, and the other in primary school. Doris lives with her husband and children in a family house in the farming/commercial town of Takorase, near Akim Oda, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Doris' husband trades in cocoa seeds.

Doris trades in palm oil. She prepares the oil and distributes it to retailers who come from other towns to buy the oil in gallons. She procures the palm nuts from farmers in nearby towns. Doris has been in business for five years and wants to expand her trade. She hopes to improve her standard of living and give her children the best education she can.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Ann Adhiambo

texts.en:
Ann Adhiambo O. is the 30-year-old mother of one four-year-old child who just started school. She is married to a man who works in Milymani Resort, a hotel in the nicest part of Kisumu that has a 60s era art-deco swimming pool. To supplement her husband’s income, she sells vegetables and tomatoes in Kasawino, which is next to the Nyamasaria slum.

Right now, she makes around 1500 Kenyan Shillings (about US $19) in profit a week. Ann hopes to expand her business and wants the loan to buy more Irish potatoes, Sukumawiki and rice. If she cannot make a larger profit, she will use the loan to pay for her child’s school fees. She is asking for 10,000 shillings.

Ann recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Foods for resale or school fees

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric O. is a 46-year-old married man and father of three children, one of whom is a boy. According to him, all of his children are in school pursuing education at senior and junior high school levels. His wife is a hard-working woman. She is a trader. Eric lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Oda, a busy trading and farming community in the Eastern Region of Ghana. 

Eric runs a grocery store by the roadside. He procures his stock of grocery from suppliers who come to distribute in vans. Eric has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure more goods to increase his inventory. He is hopeful that he will be able to increase his working capital and help him improve his savings to support his family, especially, his kids education.

loans.use: To procure groceries.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a 28-year-old mother of two children aged 3 and 4. She sells cereals like maize, rice and beans that she purchases from Uganda. Generally, wholesalers come in by sailboat to Dunga Beach in Kisumu, where the storekeepers make purchases. She sells her cereals in a small kiosk in the Kibuye market, Kisumu’s largest open-air market. She is asking for 10,000 KSH to increase her stock because she lacks the finances to do so herself.

Judith recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive-health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Cereal stock

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace B. is 50 years old. She is widowed and has given birth to six children, three sons and three daughters, who are all still in school. Some are in senior-high school, others are in junior-high school and some are also in primary school. Grace lives with the children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Grace trades in palm oil. She prepares the oil and distributes it to retailers who come from other towns to buy in gallons. She procures the palm nuts from farmers in nearby towns. Grace has been in business for 10 years and desires to expand her business. She hopes to improve upon her standard of living and give her children the best education.

loans.use: To procure palm nuts

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa D. is fifty-four years old. She is married and has eight children, three daughters and five sons. She says almost all her children are out of school. The last two are currently in senior high school.

Yaa lives with her husband and some of her children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town called Takorase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She is a trader. She trades in all kinds of footwear and printed textiles. Yaa procures the footwear and the printed textiles from Accra and sells in her community by hawking. She says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Yaa has been in business for seven years and desires to expand her business. She is hopeful of improving upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy footwear and textiles for resale

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet K. is a 45-year-old trader, who is married and has a child. Her son, Stephen K., is currently in senior high school and writing his final year examination. Her husband is a cocoa farmer and crop farmer. She sells yam tubers on a tabletop in the local market of Oda, in the eastern region of Ghana where she lives. She says that through this business, she has endeavored to support her child, who is almost finished with senior high school.
